body: I disagree with Jay in putting it in kafka-topics.sh for the reasons I stated above. Changing replication factor is a heavy-weight operation.

@hachikuji please kindly take some time to review. Thanks.

@guozhangwang But could it not happen, that `committed()` does return a valid offset, but later when we call `poll()` the offset did "expire" already -- ie, we do have a race condition. For this case, `poll()` would "fail" (if my understanding is correct) and global reset strategy would be applied -- even if a stream specific strategy got specified via API.
Even if this seems to be a very rare corner case, checking for an exception in `poll()` and set global reset strategy to `none` seems the save way to implement it.
Updated tests... and the main code as well... Sorry, sometimes it's hard to stop :)

@lindong28 `FetcherTest` has a test or two that do validation of metrics, might be worth adding a few assertions to validate this change (and maybe a test if both lag and non-lag conditions aren't available in existing tests).
Only worrying about 1 & 2 for internal topics seems reasonable to me.

@ewencp, that's a fair point about smaller PRs being easier to review. I removed the controversial change and hopefully addressed your other point. If you are happy with this as it is, I am happy for it to go in as it is and for additional changes to be submitted as separate PRs.

Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

@ewencp 

I did some fix over the wrong calculation of perf measurement codes (see the commit list) 
and also compared the perf of DefaultPartitioner.partition() method, 

below are some test result on my local machine, which shows there's almost no impact ( or very small that is going to impact even this is a heavy called function). 

anyway after first call,  it's just one additional ConcurrentHashMap.get(topic), which is a in memory call and highly optimized within JDK.  

I do not think it will impact any. 

how do you see the 30% performance hit? could you share your test codes? 

I am testing on this commit: 
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2128/commits/c5d0bb0f0422d3bed11a00b9db2b12a2ad67c18d
JDK 1.8.0_65

new partitioner, 100 thread, 1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.002445
old partitioner, 100 thread, 1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.002488

new partitioner, 10 thread, 1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.000322
old partitioner, 10 thread, 1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.000473

new partitioner, 1  thread, 1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.000122
old partitioner, 1 thread,  1000000 loop, avg partition time(ms)=0.000114
Given how old 0.8.2 is and the fact that we haven't published Scala 2.12 JARs for 0.9.0.x or 0.10.0.x, it seems unlikely that we'll publish Scala JARs for 0.8.2.

@ewencp 
in terms of the test failure, I fixed the initial checkstyle failures there. 
However, for other failures, it looks to me that some tests are not stable themselves. 
I looked the test history of this PR, on the same commit, 
sometimes the same JDK version/scala version test will fail and sometimes they will pass. 

and taking some quick look and local test, it seems the failures are not related to my changes. 
let me know if I am wrong and I will try to fix the failures if due to my changes.

@garmes-gdev, the old version only needs to be kept if there's a reason to do so (maybe the new version is missing some functionality or is not as stable). If there is no reason to keep the old version, then we can simply replace it.

@guozhangwang There are many reasons that can close the connection, it will be better if there are some useful information in the log. 

A few days ago, I found that my colleague's consumer often stopped to consume messages. And I could not find any immediate reason in the log, so I modify the kafka source code and found that the reason is a  interrupt of the consumer thread.

@guozhangwang @mjsax 

Would it make sense to combine the approaches? 

Meaning we implement the process suggested by @guozhangwang but still set the config to "none" leaving the try/catch logic to guard against the edge case described by @mjsax? 

EDIT: We would still capture the original "global" setting of the user and use that config if the stream in question did not have a specific reset policy set.

thanks @ewencp for your comments. updated few more tests for illustration purpose.will create another PR for bulk changes on hamcrest eventually. the idea is once this PR is in, people can start using hamcrest in their tests as well.thanks, and a happy new year!

Today I find one question,  If I specify Specify a chroot path  such as zookeeper.chroot =/kafak on the kafka  
The default path ZkUtils is/root directory(kafka.utils.ZkUtils) 

 val ConsumersPath = "/consumers"
  val BrokerIdsPath = "/brokers/ids"
  val BrokerTopicsPath = "/brokers/topics"
  val TopicConfigPath = "/config/topics"
  val TopicConfigChangesPath = "/config/changes"
  val ControllerPath = "/controller"
  val ControllerEpochPath = "/controller_epoch"
  val ReassignPartitionsPath = "/admin/reassign_partitions"
  val DeleteTopicsPath = "/admin/delete_topics"
  val PreferredReplicaLeaderElectionPath = "/admin/preferred_replica_election"

such variables is that started with /  rather than /kafka

Thanks @rekhajoshm. Unfortunately, these updates don't seem to improve the code. As far as I can tell, Hamcrest is beneficial when assertions like contains and such are needed. For simple `equals` and `null`, the simple methods are actually more concise.
One other thing: I think it may be better to go directly to JUnit 5 (once we move to Java 8) instead of introducing Hamcrest right now.

I think it is still safe to proceed the operation while filtering out the invalid config. I remember we did the same in some other console admin tools but I am not sure if it is still the case.
